book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: First: That he clears the Najdis of that accusation, even if the speech has no relation to them, so that they be pleased with him and not think ill of him. As for others besides these, from the Salafis and others of the people of Tawhid whom Abu Ghuddah slanders with what preceded, continuing to think ill of him, that is something that does not concern him now. Because the measure for him is not the pleasure of Allah and distance from His wrath, but rather maintaining the job that generates for him money and material gains. Otherwise, tell me by your Lord, why did he turn away from answering what Abu Ghuddah was accused of regarding his accusing the Syrian Salafis? He did not determine his stance towards accusing them with what preceded, neither negatively nor positively. For example, he did not say: Yes, they are as we said previously "their souls are disgusted or shrink when they hear the mention of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him". Nor did he say as we hoped he would say: "Glory to You, this is a great slander" and I did not say anything of what the commentator on the book "Sufism" attributed to me. But to evade, and turn away from saying anything about the Salafis while they are the ones he accused of that lie directly, and turn the speech to the Najdis who have no mention at all in the accusation attributed to him and which he quoted in his "Words", rather it is against the Salafis in Aleppo specifically. How worthy he is of the proverb that says: "Is it evasion, O Fox, when you are caught in the ropes". In summary, at the time Abu Ghuddah wants to prove that the accusation attributed to him is only a fabrication against him, he suddenly convicts himself by himself, and verifies the accusation in his person, confirming the saying of the Exalted: {but the evil plot encompasses only its own people} [Fatir: 43] and realizing the proverb saying: "He fled from death and into death he fell" and "Baraqish brought it upon herself". And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, spoke the truth when saying: "Whoever says about a believer what is not in him, Allah will lodge him in Radghat

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: al-Khabal, until he comes out of what he said, and he is not coming out." It is an authentic Hadith extracted in "Al-Sahihah" (438) and "Irwa al-Ghalil" (2376). And Radghat al-Khabal is, as in another Hadith, the sweat of the people of Hell or the juice of the people of Hell. We seek refuge in Allah from it, from its causes, and those who take to it! And if Abu Ghuddah has declared in his saying quoted previously from him: "Whoever's soul is disgusted by the mention of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, is outside the religion (Millah) with certainty" - and this in itself is true without doubt - and he was still accusing the Salafis of the mentioned disgust as preceded in explanation and his conviction of it, then it results from these two premises that the Salafis according to him are disbelievers (Kuffar) outside the religion of Islam with certainty. Some readers may insist on clearing Abu Ghuddah of accusing the Salafis of the mentioned disgust despite Abu Ghuddah's lack of denying it if he found a way to do so - due to the obscenity of the accusation, its atrocity, and the evil result of Takfir from it. But what do the readers say about his other accusation of them which is: "That they belittle (sic) the status of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him". This accusation is recorded on a tape preserved with me as preceded, and we are ready to let whoever doubts that hear Abu Ghuddah's voice saying that verbatim with his grammatical error indicated (!). And it is no less than the previous one in obscenity and atrocity. And such accusations which Abu Ghuddah throws among people recklessly are "a habit we know from Akhzam", which he is not unique in - unfortunately - but rather it is a known Sunnah (way) for all enemies of the Sunnah and Hadith without any fear or sense of responsibility in every time and place, that they accuse them of what they are innocent of. And if the noble readers know that the Master of Humanity, upon him be peace and blessings,

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: was accused by his enemies of being a poet, a sorcerer, a madman, is it not more appropriate that the enemies of the Sunnah accuse the people of the Sunnah of what they are innocent of? And if it is difficult for them to believe these false accusations issuing from Abu Ghuddah on the pretext that it is not written in any of his books, let them know that the proof is established by other than books as well, even according to Abu Ghuddah himself. For he said in his "Words" (p. 21): "However, I challenge any human to prove that I said anything of this which they claimed falsely and slanderously - in my books and lessons - or in what I classified or authored." As for the first accusation - the accusation of disgust - his admission of it and his lack of initiative to deny it as preceded is sufficient to prove it issued from him. Even if we assume he rectified the matter after we compelled him with his declaring Salafis disbelievers, and as per the common proverb "In the summer you wasted the milk", at that point names of upright eyewitnesses who testify against him regarding that emerge. Therefore, it is better for him to confess that his declaration of that was a slip by which Satan misled him, so he repents from it, and perhaps he will do so. If he does not do so, then it is arrogance itself about which the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "He will not enter Paradise who has in his heart a mustard seed's weight of arrogance." Then he explained it by saying: "Arrogance is rejecting the truth (meaning rejecting it after its appearance) and belittling people" meaning attacking them without right, exactly as Abu Ghuddah did, may Allah guide him. As for the other accusation, his voice saying it is recorded with us as we mentioned, so in that is the greatest proof of it and conviction of him with it. Then why do we go far? Here is a doctor from the doctors and teachers in a college of the Sharia colleges saying in a book of his that is printed

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: its text verbatim: "A people went astray (meaning the Salafis) whose hearts did not feel the love of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and went about denouncing Tawassul by his person, peace and blessings be upon him, after his death" (1). This is like the previous two accusations in atrocity because its meaning is also that they are disbelievers according to him. And this stupid ignorant one does not feel that senior figures whom he and his likes of the fanatical imitators obligate people to imitate, foremost among them Imam Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, have preceded us in denouncing the mentioned Tawassul. So do you think he and others are astray, O stupid one, or do you not know what comes out of your mouth?! And after, is Abu Ghuddah's saying (p. 19) truthful: "For declaring people disbelievers (Takfir), let alone scholars, is not of my nature nor my character, and praise be to Allah. For Allah the Exalted has preserved me with what He honored me with of intellect (!) and what He disciplined me with of the discipline of Islam from falling into these Expiators (Mukaffirat) and destructive sins. For whoever calls a believer a disbeliever has disbelieved"? And I say: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, spoke the truth: Whoever calls a Muslim a disbeliever has disbelieved. And if Abu Ghuddah says: The Salafis, their souls are disgusted when they hear the mention of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, then he says: Indeed whoever's soul is disgusted by the mention of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, is outside the religion (Millah) with certainty." And directly after this he clears from this disgust which expels one from the religion (the people of the Holy Lands whom

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: hundreds of thousands of pilgrims enter every year...) and does not specify the Salafis upon whom he directly poured his accusation with clearance. Does that not mean that Salafis according to him are outside the religion with certainty? So where is that nature and character he boasted about?! And here I remind him of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Any Muslim man who calls a Muslim man a disbeliever, if he was a disbeliever [it is so], otherwise he [the accuser] is the disbeliever." Perhaps he will be ashamed to claim what is not in him, and perhaps he will be deterred and refrain from declaring monotheist Muslims disbelievers, and repent to Allah from what issued from him, a sincere repentance, in which there is no equivocation or arrogance. Fourth - Among his lies that have no end: Abu Ghuddah mentioned (p. 10 - 11) what we had described him with rightfully in the "Introduction" of attributes he was clothed in in his unjust report, pretending that he is innocent of all that without trying to establish even a semblance of proof for that. A matter which makes every fair person divested of desire and purpose convict him of all that when he sees us having established proof for everything we described him with in the Introduction, and sees Abu Ghuddah repudiating that in his "Words" merely by saying: "This is explicit fabrication." Indeed, the greatest criminal on the face of the earth is not incapable of clearing himself with such a cheap saying "explicit fabrication." As for the truly innocent noble man, he is the one who refutes argument with argument and proof with proof. This is what Abu Ghuddah did not do and will not do, because he knows that if he did, he would be like the one searching for his death with his hoof. And this haste does not accommodate repeating the proofs we mentioned in the "Introduction" for what we described him with, especially since in his "Words" are

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: new examples that testify for some of the traits we described him with there, which saves me from repeating here. So let us mention some of these examples so the reader knows that Abu Ghuddah is far beyond that! New examples of that. First: He said (p. 10) mentioning the Introduction to the explanation of "Al-Aqidah Al-Tahawiyyah": "And it was stuffed with what conflicts with the loftiness of the Sublime Creed, of obscenity, defamation, stabbing, and Takfir (declaring others disbelievers)." I say: As for his saying "and Takfir", it is from his lies that indicate the hidden [evil] of his soul, to prove thereby to the readers the false myth which he and his likes of the superstitious spread that Salafis declare Muslims disbelievers. So we challenge him to prove the place where I accused him of the alleged Takfir from the "Introduction", and it is in numbered pages. If he does not do so - and he will not do so - then it has become clear to people that he is a sinful liar. And if he insists, we will do Mubahalah (invoking Allah's curse on the liar) with him if he wishes {Then whoever argues with you about it after [this] knowledge has come to you - say, "Come, let us call our sons and your sons, our women and your women, ourselves and yourselves, then supplicate earnestly [together] and invoke the curse of Allah upon the liars"} [Al Imran: 61]. As for stabbing [criticism], there is no harm on us from it, because it is with right and is legitimate as I established in the Introduction (p. 43). As for defamation (Qadhf), if he means by it insulting, then it is like stabbing and you have known its answer. He is only multiplying words for agitation. And if he means by it Qadhf of adultery, then it is a falsehood like the previous one. And similar to it is his saying: "obscenity" (Iqdha'). In Al-Qamus: "He was obscene with him (Qadha'ahu) like prevented him; he threw foulness and bad speech at him, like Aqdha'ahu"! Second: He said (p. 10 - 11): "And he described me times after times as being a Hanafi, driven in the context of taunting and insult, as they view affiliation to Imam Abu Hanifa or others of the followed glorious Imams as an insult and a deficiency."

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: So I say: Glory be to You [Allah], this is a great slander and a grave lie from such a sinful fabricator. For he knows that we are on the contrary of that, as is printed in many of my works, especially my introduction to my book 'The Prophet's Prayer Described from the Takbir to the Taslim as if You Were Seeing It'. It is fifty-nine pages long. It has been printed several times over many years, and Abu Ghuddah is certainly aware of it. But the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) spoke the truth: 'If you feel no shame, then do as you wish.' There is no harm in quoting from it what suits the context. I said therein (p. 26), after offering an excuse for Abu Hanifa, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, regarding his contradiction of some authentic Hadiths, while noting his command to his followers to act upon what is authentic according to them in many texts established from him: 'I said: If this is Abu Hanifa's excuse for what occurred from him of contradicting authentic Hadiths unintentionally—which is an excuse acceptable absolutely because Allah the Exalted does not burden a soul beyond its capacity—then it is not permissible to attack him because of it, as some ignorant people might do. Rather, it is obligatory to be polite with him because he is one of the Imams of the Muslims through whom this religion was preserved and its branches reached us. He is rewarded in any case, whether he was correct or mistaken. Likewise, it is not permissible for those who revere him to remain clinging to his statements that contradict the authentic Hadiths, for they are not [truly] from his Madhhab (school of thought), as you have seen his texts regarding that. So, these [ignorant attackers] are in one valley, and those [blind followers] are in another, and the truth is between these and those. {Our Lord, forgive us and our brothers who preceded us in faith and put not in our hearts [any] resentment toward those who have believed. Our Lord, indeed You are Kind and Merciful}.' This is a part of what I mentioned there regarding praising the followed Imams and defending some of them, and what ought to be the conduct of...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: ...their followers. It contains an explicit approval of affiliation [to a Madhhab] on the condition of prioritizing Hadith over blind imitation (Taqlid). I can summarize that here as follows: Affiliation with one of the Imams as a means to acquire knowledge of the jurisprudence of the Book and the Sunnah, which might be missed by a student of knowledge, is something inevitable religiously and practically; for that without which a duty cannot be fulfilled is itself a duty. The Salaf (predecessors) and the Khalaf (successors) all proceeded upon this, receiving knowledge one from another. However, the Khalaf—except a few of them—contradicted the Salaf when they made the means an end. They made it obligatory upon every Muslim, no matter how high he rose in knowledge and understanding of Allah and His Messenger after the four Imams, to blindly imitate one of them, never inclining away from him to another, as one of them said: 'And it is obligatory to blindly imitate a scholar among them.' The result of this was that each of them became fanatical about his Madhhab, without remembering that following a Madhhab is a means, and that the goal is following the Book and the Sunnah. So the goal became forgotten among them, and they cast the Quran behind their backs, clinging to the Madhhab and making it their religion, and showing fanaticism for it against the authentic Sunnah. Whenever you bring one of them an authentic Hadith, he turns away from it and distances himself. Among the wonders is that some of them justify this by saying: 'We are prisoners of the texts,' meaning the sayings of the scholars despite the contradiction and difference existing between them within a single Madhhab, let alone other Madhhabs. So we said: We are also prisoners, but with a big difference; we are prisoners of the infallible texts of the Book and the Sunnah, which are protected from difference and disturbance {If it had been from [any] other than Allah, they would have found within it much contradiction}. As for you, you are prisoners of texts that are different and disturbed with much contradiction, in which the skilled guide among you in traditional Fiqh is confused in reconciling them or preferring one aspect of...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: ...disagreement within them! Here, desire, habit, and pleasing the rabble and the common folk intervene, making them the preponderant factor whether they like it or not. So if Abu Ghuddah means by the 'affiliation' mentioned in his words this absolute affiliation which is a means and not an end—and this is what is apparent from the general nature of his words—then he has fabricated a lie against us, and Allah is his Reckoner. And if it is the affiliation that the overwhelming majority of blind imitators are upon—and this is what I do not think he can openly admit—then we say quite frankly: We view it as a disgrace and a deficiency. We add and say that this is what we received from the Imams who forbade blind imitation and made following the Book and the Sunnah obligatory in numerous texts which I covered in the Introduction referred to previously. Among that is the saying of one of them: 'No one blindly imitates except a fanatic or a fool' (1). And his saying previously: 'He described me time and time again as being a Hanafi, driven in a manner of shaming and insult.' This is of that same genre of fabrication and slander. For we do not shame anyone merely for being affiliated with Abu Hanifa or others among the Imams, may Allah have mercy on them all. Rather, we shame the one who is fanatical about his Madhhab, preferring it over the Book of his Lord and the Sunnah of his Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). And Abu Ghuddah is of this type, decidedly severe in his fanaticism for his Madhhab, proud of it. For he praises Allah for...

Examples of His Fanaticism

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:

His Answer to Some Questions and an Explanation of the Prevarication It Contains Confirming His Kawtharism and Hostility to Ibn Taymiyyah
Yes, he addressed the answer to what came in the last four paragraphs with some explanation, but in reality, he was like one trying to stab the eye of the sun. See (p. 8) of...

And claims, if you do not establish for them ... evidences, their children are illegitimate.

You remain convicted of being a Kawthari in whole and in detail until you fulfill our request by declaring your dissociation from him in whole and in detail, so we may rest from you and from discussing you in whole...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:

The answer to this nonsense is from several aspects:
1 - You made the evidence that you are not committed to everything Al-Kawthari says to be that you do not shun the two Sheikhs as your Sheikh Al-Kawthari used to shun them. Your master Abu al-Hasanat al-Lucknawi declared this in 'Al-Fawa'id Al-Bahiyyah' (1). Therefore, this proof of yours bears witness against you that you are a Kawthari in everything we described Al-Kawthari with regarding misguidance and deviation from the Salaf and the Imams of Hadith. Had it not been so, you would have declared your dissociation from all that just as you declared your dissociation from his shunning of the two Sheikhs, especially since we opened the way for you to do so by asking you to announce your dissociation from all that. Does a rational person interpret your refusal to announce it as anything other than a decisive proof that you are a Kawthari one hundred...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
...percent? And now we say: one hundred except one, after your admission of dissociating from your Sheikh's shunning of the two Sheikhs, and Allah is your Reckoner! 2 - You say that you praised the two Sheikhs, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on them: The answer is that such praise for them—with which you blackened numerous pages of your 'Words' by quoting from your commentaries on some books—does not indicate to the people of knowledge and understanding that you hold a good belief regarding them or that, in your opinion, there is no deviation in their knowledge. The evidence is that all those words do not contain a single sentence, nay, not even a fragment, from which one can smell your appreciation of them in their creed and that they are not deviant in their knowledge. Examples of His Attack on Ibn Taymiyyah and Ibn al-Qayyim
And something else: It is that your praise might fool those who have no knowledge of what issued from you of attacks on their creed and knowledge. I am not...

text:
...holding you accountable for what issued from you in some of your sermons in your city Aleppo, for that is a matter that goes back to others whom you accuse of lying against you. Rather, I will convict you with what your pen, deviant from the two Sheikhs, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on them, wrote:
1 - You approved in your commentary on the book 'Iqamat al-Hujjah' (p. 29)—authored according to what is mentioned in Ibn Taymiyyah's biography—that he [the author] quoted from him [Ibn Taymiyyah] corrupt beliefs for which Al-Yafi'i, Ibn Hajar al-Makki, and others reviled him! It should be believed about him that he is a stray innovator, a misleading ignorant extremist. May Allah treat him with His justice, and may He save us from the likes of his path, his creed, and his deed, and may He forsake his followers and scatter the gathering of those who believe in him.' That is what enemies of Sheikh Ibn Taymiyyah did before Abu Ghuddah, like Sheikh Muhammad Bakhit al-Muti'i in the treatise 'Tathir al-Fu'ad min Danas al-I'tiqad' (Purifying the Heart from the Filth of Belief); he attacked Ibn Taymiyyah therein as his desire dictated, relying in that on the word of Ibn Hajar al-Makki referred to in 'Al-Fatawa' and quoting it in its entirety!!

text:
2 - The author of 'Al-Raf' wal-Takmil' (p. 90-91 and 135) and in 'Al-Ajwibah Al-Fadilah' (p. 174) approved of grouping Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah in the faction of those who are obstinate in criticizing Hadiths by criticizing their narrators. book_title: كشف النقاب عما في «كلمات» أبي غدة من الأباطيل والافتراءات
text: «He is Shafi'i in the branches [of jurisprudence] but an anthropomorphist (Mujassim) in belief, despite his disavowal of it in many places. book_title: كشف النقاب عما في «كلمات» أبي غدة من الأباطيل والافتراءات
text: He says this while knowing that his Sheikh Al-Kawthari declares Ibn Taymiyyah and Ibn al-Qayyim disbelievers and places them, regarding exiting Islam and the Muslims, like the heretics (Zanadiqah), as mentioned previously. book_title: كشف النقاب عما في «كلمات» أبي غدة من الأباطيل والافتراءات
text: Then Abu Ghuddah focused his speech on Al-Thanawi's saying: «And where is it for Ibn Taymiyyah to be like the dust of his sandal», and criticized him for this phrase and wrote to Al-Thanawi about it until he retracted it. The noble reader will notice that Abu Ghuddah only concerned himself with a formal aspect, using that as a means to show his reverence for Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah and his lack of Takfir towards him. He missed that what was more deserving of his criticism of Al-Thanawi was his claim that «Al-Tahawi's rank in the science of Hadith is above thousands like Ibn Taymiyyah» and his saying about him that he is among the «hardliners» (Mutashaddidin). So, Abu Ghuddah turning away from criticizing him in these two matters is the greatest proof of his agreement with him on them. This is supported by what was previously quoted from Abu Ghuddah regarding his inclusion of Ibn Taymiyyah in the group of hardliners, following his Sheikh Al-Kawthari. So where is the reverence and respect for Ibn Taymiyyah he claimed, while he looks at him with that contemptuous, degraded view in Hadith, and that he is among the hardliners?! Know, O noble reader, that we do not rule out that Abu Ghuddah might honor Ibn Taymiyyah in one of the attributes existing in him, such as his asceticism, his knowledge in Tafsir, Hadith, and Usul, etc., and his patience with trials and tribulations. Therefore, what he claims of praise for Ibn Taymiyyah and defense of him is from this perspective. This, naturally, does not contradict that he believes regarding him that he is misguided and deviant from the creed, such as [accusing him of] anthropomorphism and other things his Sheikh Al-Kawthari accuses him of. This is one thing and that is another. text: and what our Master the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, affirmed for Him, without interpretation (Ta'wil), distortion (Tahrif), likening (Tashbih), or representation (Tamthil). {There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the Hearing, the Seeing}». All Muslims say the likes of this statement of yours, even your Sheikh Al-Kawthari, despite his great misguidance, cannot say other than that—despite his attacking the protectors of the Salafi creed—otherwise, if he said other than that, the cover would be revealed. The answer: The Doctrine of the Salaf in Attributes and the Stance of Preachers Today Regarding It. 1 - The Salaf describe Allah the Exalted with what He described Himself with in

text: His Book or what His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, reported about Him, and they believe in that as He described Himself *in reality (Haqiqatan)* without interpretation (Ta'wil)... etc. This word «Haqiqatan» (in reality) is the distinguishing characteristic of the Salafi over others from the Khalafis (Later Generations). For the latter are of two sections: A section of Tafwid (Relegators) who believe in the wordings of the verses and hadiths of Attributes without believing in the realities of their meanings that befit Allah the Exalted. Among them is your Sheikh Al-Kawthari; indeed, he is the flag bearer of this deviation in the present era. And you, when you said: «without interpretation nor distortion...» have removed yourself—albeit with your tongue, and Allah is your Reckoner and Questioner about what is in your heart—from this last section. But you did not remove yourself from being among the Mufawwidah (Relegators) whose faith stops at the wordings without the meanings! So, I wonder, did you intentionally not add the word «Haqiqatan» (in reality) to your previous speech in order to mislead the readers so they would testify for you that you are Salafi! Or is it that you yourself do not know the difference between the two aforementioned sections?! If you do not know, then that is a calamity... and if you know, then the calamity is greater.

text: And Allah bears witness that it pleases and gladdens me that you be sincere in this declaration of yours in which you deny the interpretation (Ta'wil) that your Sheikh Al-Kawthari subscribed to, which led him to exit the path of the Salaf one hundred percent, and even drove him to attack the creed of the Salaf and to interpret their words that contradict his school of thought regarding the verses and hadiths of Attributes. In that case, there is no great benefit from your denial of interpretation because you did not believe in what corresponds to it, which is belief in His Attributes, the Exalted, in reality (Haqiqatan) as befits Him, Glorified and Exalted. Either it is of the type {They say with their tongues what is not in their hearts} or of the type of the hypocrite's saying when asked in the grave about the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: «I do not know, I say as the people say». You heard the monotheist scholars of Najd denying interpretation, so you spoke with their saying without understanding its implication, which is belief in the Attributes

text: in reality (Haqiqatan), no interpretation and no relegation. For this statement of theirs implied: That (Hanafi Fiqh and the like) is not from our Sharia and is not from the Book and the Sunnah.’

Clarification of the lying and misguidance in his speech regarding the ‘Footnote of Mukhtasar Muslim’
I say: In this speech, there is lying and misguidance that would not issue from a person who respects his religion and his intellect, let alone respecting his brothers and friends. Here is the clarification:
First: We have proven previously his lie regarding what he attributed and attributes to us of attacking the Madhhabs and that we consider affiliation to them an insult and a disgrace. This is an open lie, and the explanation of that has preceded in detail, so we will not return to it. If this misguided one makes repeating the accusation regarding that his habit, then Allah is his Reckoner.
Second: His saying ‘And they removed them (i.e., the Madhhabs) from the circle of our Sharia and from the Book and the Sunnah and claimed that they are other than them.’

Our Position on the Madhhabs
So I say: This is also a lie with this generalization. No Muslim on the face of the earth says that. For it is known by necessity that in the Madhhabs there are many, very many issues agreed upon among Muslims, and they have their evidences from the Book and the Sunnah. And in every one of them, regarding what they differed in, there is much correctness which is preponderant by evidence from the Book and the Sunnah. However, opposite this, there are many issues in every Madhhab which were based...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: ...on Ijtihad and opinion, and the Sunnah indicated their error. So the mistaken one in them is rewarded with a single reward. Therefore, when the scholar Ibn Daqiq al-Eid, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, collected the issues in which the Madhhab of each of the four Imams contradicted the authentic Hadith, individually and collectively, in a huge volume, he mentioned in its beginning that attributing these issues to the Mujtahid Imams is prohibited (Haram), and that it is obligatory upon the Jurists who blindly follow them to know them so that they do not attribute them to them, and thus lie about them (1). Because of that, the prohibition of blind imitation was authentic from the four Imams, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on them, as well as the command to return to the Book and the Sunnah, as is detailed in the beginning of my book ‘The Prophet’s Prayer Described...’ and others. In it is an explanation of the middle position that a Muslim should take towards the Imams, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on them. Abu Ghuddah is aware of that, but he is arrogant according to his habit and attributes to me what he himself knows to be false; so Allah is his Reckoner. Because of this type of issue which contradicts the Sunnah in every Madhhab of the four Madhhabs, let alone others, it is not permissible to say that they are the Book and the Sunnah, and that they, with all the details and errors they contain, are from our Sharia. And if Imam Ibn Daqiq al-Eid prohibits, as preceded, attributing these issues to the four Imams, then how is it permissible to attribute them to the Islamic Sharia?! Therefore, I absolved Isa, peace be upon him, from ruling by one of the Madhhabs when I said, commenting on the statement of Imam Ibn Abi Dhi’b, the narrator of the Hadith: ‘How will you be when the son of Mary descends among you and your Imam is from you?’ Ibn Abi Dhi’b said explaining it: ‘And leads you by the Book of your Lord and the Sunnah of your Prophet.’ So I said commenting on it:
foot_note: 1. (1) ‘Iqaz al-Himam’ by Sheikh Salih al-Fullani, may Allah have mercy on him.

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: ‘This is explicit that Isa, peace be upon him, will rule by our Sharia, and judge by the Book and the Sunnah, not by other than them such as the Gospel, or Hanafi Fiqh and the like.’ By mentioning the Gospel, I indicated the refutation of the Christians who claim that Isa, upon his descent, will not rule by the Quran, but rather by the Gospel. And by mentioning Hanafi Fiqh, [I intended] the refutation of some Hanafi fanatics who assert that Isa, peace be upon him, will rule by the Hanafi Madhhab. And I intended by my saying: ‘and the like’ to repel what might cross the mind of some Hanafi fanatics that my mentioning of Hanafi Fiqh without others is only fanaticism from me against it and an inclination towards others. So I said: ‘and the like’ to equate between it and all the Madhhabs in that Isa will not rule by any of them, but rather by the Book and the Sunnah only. It would not have crossed the mind that this brief speech would be exploited with such a cheap exploitation as issued from Abu Ghuddah previously and subsequently. As for previously, that was when the book was printed in its first edition; he raised the world and did not sit it down, by spreading rumors among people that Al-Albani attacks the four Madhhabs and that it is not permissible to affiliate with them just as it is not permissible to affiliate with the Gospel, and similar falsehoods which he has now expressed in writing in his ‘Words’. How many a person asked me about this rumor, and my answer to it was: Glory be to You, this is a great slander. When we knew that day that its source was Abu Ghuddah, I hastened to write a retraction (Istidrak) in which I included the refutation of this rumor and its invalidation, while indicating that the one who took charge of the greater part of it was one of the Hanafi fanatics. I clarified therein this brief comment similar to what the publisher of the second edition clarified in his introduction to the second edition. I sent the retraction to the agent of the first publisher, and the one in charge of printing the book in Beirut at that time, so that he would print the retraction and append it...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
...to the book before its distribution. I followed that with a telegram I sent to the publisher while he was in Kuwait, hoping that the book would not go down to the markets before the retraction came to him printed to be appended to the book. I followed it with a letter I sent to him detailing the matter. But the book was distributed without the retraction! It was said that the reason is that Abu Ghuddah is a friend of that agent, and he used to visit him at that time, so he showed him the retraction, and he advised him against publishing it. So he had what he wanted. Months later, I met the publisher and asked him about the reason for not publishing the retraction, and he answered with an answer that was of no avail. I do not know until today what the proportion of responsibility he bears is for not printing the mentioned retraction.
Thirdly: Among the wonders is that the publisher referred to is one of Abu Ghuddah’s intimate friends, and he still sells his books, with all the attacks on the Imams contained therein, in his library in Kuwait until today. Abu Ghuddah knows with certainty that he is the publisher, yet he holds him, also, responsible for my saying in the footnote by associating him with me in his usual lie: ‘their saying.’ The speaker is only me alone, and the publisher or the printer has no relation to it. Look at him how he says: ‘So this is their saying in the footnote of “Mukhtasar Muslim...” printed in Kuwait...’ for he usually means by such a phrase: ‘their saying’ the author and the publisher of his books, who is Brother Zuhair Al-Shawish ‘owner of the well-known office (Al-Maktab Al-Islami)’! But his unjust habit overcame him, so he meant with me someone other than him among the publishers, namely the first Kuwaiti-Egyptian publisher, and he is one of his intimate friends as we mentioned. So he harmed him while he did not perceive, which reminds me of the famous proverb: ‘A rational enemy is better than an ignorant friend’!
Fourthly: His saying ‘Printed in Kuwait in the first and second editions’ is a misleading intended by him, for he knows that it was printed in Beirut...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
...the first and second editions, and the publisher of the second edition, Brother Al-Shawish, stated that explicitly in the introduction to the second edition. Abu Ghuddah is aware of it, as is explicit in his statement. His purpose behind this misleading is to divert people from what was attributed to him regarding his striving with the one in charge of the first edition in Beirut not to print the retraction referred to previously.
Fifthly: His saying: ‘And far be it that they cover up what issued from them with any interpretation or justification.’ I said: This is from the arrogance of this unjust fanatic and his denial of facts. He calls the clarification and explanation which the publisher printed in the introduction to the second edition a cover-up! If we wished to treat him with the likes of this action of his, we would have said that his authoring of this treatise of his ‘Words in Unveiling Falsehoods and Fabrications’ is only a cover-up for his falsehoods, fabrications, and swindling of people, and that would be enough. We would not have wasted time precious to us in uncovering it accompanied by evidence and proof as is the methodology of the Quran {Say, "Bring your proof, if you should be truthful."} As for Abu Ghuddah, you see him launching his speech without restraint regarding the falsehoods and accusations he hurls at his opponent without attempting to support that with evidence. But in reality, he is excused in his own eyes, because he knows that he has no evidence for that; that is why he suffices with biting and squeaking?

Clarification of the Intent of the Footnote on ‘The Mukhtasar’ and the Claim of Some Hanafis regarding Isa, Peace Be Upon Him
To confirm that, I transfer to the noble readers the text of the word of the virtuous publisher, Mr. Zuhair Al-Shawish—may Allah reward him with good—in the introduction to the second edition, after he pointed to my comment which the unjust fanatic exploited. He said:

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: ‘The restriction in the commentary was to what the verifier (Al-Albani) saw as sufficient. However, those with agendas exploited that comment in the worst exploitation. The argument of the verifier therein is the refutation of the fanatics who emulated, by their speech and their fanaticism for their Imam and their Madhhab, the saying of the misguided ones who claimed that our Master the Messenger of Allah [Isa] (Isa son of Mary, peace be upon him, comes confirming what they are upon of disbelief in Allah and in Isa and his mother the Virgin. The reality is that the statement of the verifier was a refutation of what came in letters, fatwas, and sayings claiming that our Master Isa, peace be upon him, will rule by the Hanafi Madhhab when he descends at the end of time. They deduce that based on the story of a silly dream narrated by an unknown person who says that the sayings of his Madhhab remain preserved in a box in the Jayhun river, containing what Abu Hanifa taught Al-Khidr. Before Isa descends, the Quran and knowledge will be lifted, so Isa will go to the river confused, seeking knowledge from the river, and a hand will emerge for him holding the box of knowledge which Al-Khidr deposited in the river from what he learned from Imam Abu Hanifa, may Allah's mercy be upon him). This is what the verifier refuted with one brief line, the meaning of which the people of knowledge know, thinking that this refutation would be an aid to them in deducing with the Hadith of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: “How will you be when he descends...”’—so he mentioned the Hadith—and the preceding comment upon it. Then the brother, publisher of the second edition, said: ‘Among those who narrated the story of the river, Al-Khidr, and Abu Hanifa is Imam Al-Haskafi, who is among the senior men of the Madhhab of Imam Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, in the introduction of his famous book (Al-Durr Al-Mukhtar), upon which the footnote of Ibn Abidin was placed; [it is] the greatest of the books of the Hanafis in the later ages, rather it is one of the most important references for Islamic jurisprudence as a whole. The verifier avoided mentioning the story in detail, because pursuing...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
...the slips of scholars is of what we were forbidden from, and he sufficed with refuting the fabrication to those who knew it. By that, he prevented the spreading of what indicates relying in beliefs and rulings on dreams and incorrect sayings, as some do. If those who exploited the comment and acted according to it had realized that, it would have been better for them.’
Sixthly: He said following what preceded: ‘And this statement of theirs implied: “That Hanafi Fiqh and the like” is not from our Sharia and is not from the Book and the Sunnah.’
I say: This is a repetition of his preceding saying: ‘And they removed them from the circle of our Sharia...’ The lying and misleading therein, and the correct view which we believe regarding the Madhhabs—and whether it is said they are from the Sharia absolutely or not—has already been explained, so there is no need for repetition.

A Question to ‘Abu Ghuddah’: Will He Answer?
But I want to ask this fanatic who tries to fish in troubled waters: The concept of this speech of yours...—and the concepts of books are considered valid according to the Hanafis—is that Hanafi Fiqh is entirely from the Book and the Sunnah. So do you say this?! If you answer in the negative, then you have come to my saying, so what do you deny of me?! And if you answer in the affirmative, you have revealed your misguidance and contradiction! As for the misguidance, it is that in the Hanafi Madhhab—like other Madhhabs—there are many issues contrary to the evidences of the Book and the Sunnah as previously explained and supported by the words of Ibn Daqiq al-Eid. So if you say: ‘They are from the Book and the Sunnah,’ you have attributed difference, contradiction, and error to the Sharia, and Allah Almighty and Exalted says {If it had been from [any] other than Allah...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text: ...they would have found within it much contradiction}. There is no misguidance beyond that misguidance. As for the contradiction, it is that you admitted in your ‘Words’ (p. 44) that in ‘every Madhhab there are odd branches which are not acted upon.’ So how can it be said: That Hanafi Fiqh is entirely from our Sharia while it contains oddities that are not acted upon?! Does anyone utter the likes of this except a fool who does not know what comes out of his mouth? Then he does not suffice with this stupidity until he adds another to it, denouncing the one who denies that everything in Hanafi Fiqh is from the Islamic Sharia! I say this, and I do not rule it out for such a fool (1) to combine contradictories in his mind. For sometimes he speaks what is correct, like his admission of the existence of odd branches in the Hanafi Madhhab that are not acted upon. And sometimes he says what reminds us of the major misguidance which says: ‘Every Mujtahid is correct’ and that the Madhhabs, with the wide difference between them, are like multiple Sharias; there is no harm on a Muslim to take from whichever of them he wills and leave what he wills, for all is Sharia (2). For he commented on the saying of Sheikh Al-Qari in ‘Fath Bab Al-Inayah’ (1/261): ‘And one prays on a garment whose lining is impure according to Muhammad, and according to Abu Yusuf it is not permissible.’ Then he quoted from the footnote of Ibn Abidin that he said: The apparent meaning of ‘Al-Bada’i’ is preferring the saying of Muhammad, and it is the most similar [to the truth], but in ‘Al-Hashiyah’ he preferred the saying of ‘Abu Yusuf’. Abu Ghuddah said: ‘So the two sayings are preferred; acting upon either of them is permissible’! Does this not indicate that Abu Ghuddah sees that the contradictory sayings...

1. (1) He is the fool. 
2. See ‘Sifat al-Salat’ p. 44-49.

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
...—and how many they are in his Madhhab—are all Sharia, and it is permissible to act upon whatever you wish of them? Someone might say: Perhaps this is specific to what was of difference within the Hanafi Madhhab only! I say: No, for I saw him prefer the Madhhab of Imam Malik regarding the permissibility of a menstruating woman and a woman in post-natal bleeding reading the Quran and touching the Mushaf for learning and teaching, and the permissibility of a person in a state of major ritual impurity (Junub) reading what is customary to seek refuge with, like Ayat al-Kursi, Surah Al-Ikhlas, and the two Surahs of Refuge (Al-Mu'awwidhatayn) upon fear or sleep... etc., of what he explicitly permitted contrary to his Hanafi Madhhab which does not permit that. He concluded his speech by saying: ‘And in this is from the tolerance of Islam and its spaciousness in facilitating the maintenance of performing the litanies required of the believer to read upon his sleep, even if he is Junub or menstruating or in post-natal bleeding’ (1). So I say: But in your Hanafi Madhhab—which you worship Allah by—is the opposite of what you mentioned of tolerance and facilitation, and it is by your admission (p. 40) nothing other than the Islamic Sharia which is the Book and the Sunnah. So is Islam according to you two religions, one of them ease and the other hardship?! So take lesson, O people of vision.
And now, after this clarification and before moving to the refutation of him regarding the...
foot_note: 1. (1) From his commentary on ‘Fath Bab Al-Inayah’ (1/218). I say: If any of the Salafis had chosen such an opinion contrary to his Madhhab, Abu Ghuddah would have shouted and his jugular veins would have swelled out of zeal for his Madhhab and attacking the supporters of the Sunnah for their Ijtihad and their contradiction of their Madhhab. We have mentioned previously his attack in the Friday sermon against them for such contradiction. But as for him, if he performs Ijtihad and contradicts, it is permissible. So, what is not permissible for others is permissible for him! Is this not what confirms our previous description of him as weighing with two scales and measuring with two measures?

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
...last of what he uttered of falsehood and ignorance, I want to ask the unjust fanatic for his opinion on the following:
1 - We believe that Isa, when he descends, will rule by the Book and the Sunnah, and not by a Madhhab of the four Madhhabs. So do you believe that with us, or do you believe the opposite which we refuted in our brief comment?
2 - We believe that in every Madhhab of the Madhhabs there is right and wrong, and there is no Madhhab infallible from error. So do you believe this with us, or do you say: Your Hanafi Madhhab is all correct, and the Madhhab of others is all wrong?
If you say in both of the questions in agreement with what we hold, then it has become apparent to the readers that your refutation of us is merely disputing with falsehood and fishing in troubled waters out of malice, envy, and seeking ingratiation with the common folk who think, because of people like you, that the follower of a Madhhab is more deserving of being followed, and that the truth* is multiple, and in all that they say: ‘And all of them are seeking from the Messenger of Allah.’
And if your answer is contrary to our belief, then you are at that time, along with your misguidance, contradictory as previously explained. So we ask Allah for guidance to the truth and noble character!
I add now and say: Abu Ghuddah said in his commentary on ‘Al-Tasrih bima Tawatara fi Nuzul al-Masih’ (p. 58): ‘And the scholar Al-Alusi said in his Tafsir: “Then indeed Isa, peace be upon him, when he descends, remains upon his previous prophethood; he is not removed from it in any case. However, he does not worship by it because of its abrogation in his right and the right of others. His obligation is with the rulings of this Sharia, in principles and branches. So there will be no revelation to him, peace be upon him, nor establishing of rulings. Rather, he will be...
foot_note: 1. * (because of people like you, that the follower of a Madhhab is more deserving of being followed, and that the truth) fell out of the second edition, and I retrieved it from the first edition of the book. [Preparer of the book for Al-Maktaba Al-Shamila]

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
...a successor to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and a ruler among the rulers of his nation among his Ummah by what he knew in the heaven before his descent of his Sharia [Muhammad’s], upon him be blessings and peace, as is in some reports”.’ Abu Ghuddah quoted this and approved it and did not critique it with anything, which indicates in its totality that he has accepted it for himself as a Madhhab. Based on this, is not the meaning of that that Isa, upon him be blessings and peace, will not rule by the Hanafi Madhhab nor by others, but rather he will rule by the Book and the Sunnah? So what do you resent from us, may Allah paralyze your hand and cut your tongue?!

Seventhly and Finally: He said—may his mouth be smashed—(p. 43): ‘And they have distributed their poisons and their attacks on the followed Imams in numerous books... to achieve the goal they seek, and without the secrets of their souls which they harbor being exposed, while pretending with it jealousy for the Book and the Sunnah. For they said in the book “Hijab al-Mar’ah al-Muslimah” (p. 61) the following: The Shafi’is reasoned strangely, for they said: As for if the color—meaning the color of the Awrah in prayer—(1) is covered and the [volume of] the limbs is described, there is no harm, as if one wore tight trousers.’ They said: And it is recommended that the woman prays in a ample shirt and a veil, and takes a thick outer garment (Jilbab) over her clothes so that it hangs away from her, and the size of her limbs is not distinguished. Al-Rafi’i mentioned it in his explanation (4/92, 105 with Sharh al-Muhadhdhab). Their speech ended. Then they commented on it by their saying literally:
foot_note: 1. (1) This addition is from Abu Ghuddah for clarification and explanation, and the correct phrasing is to say: ‘meaning the color of the Awrah in prayer’.

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
‘I said: So based on this opinion of theirs, it is permissible for a woman today to go out wearing these tight clothes that stick to the body and describe it accurately, to the point that one who is far from her imagines that she is naked! Like these flesh-colored stockings that describe the volume of the shins and thighs and increase them in beauty, nay, the trousers which describe the member itself! If a woman wore such clothing, it would be permissible for her according to them because she covered the color with it, even if the woman gave a color more beautiful than her natural color! So does a Muslim say of the permissibility of this today?! This is among the many proofs for the obligation of Ijtihad and abandoning blind imitation. Is there any who will remember?!’ Their speech ended literally.’
I say: Thus did this unjust, spiteful, foolish fanatic use these words which he quoted from me as evidence for what he claimed of attacking the followed Imams... etc. of his speech which he presented before it (a trait we know from Akhzam). The one who contemplates this action of his cannot understand from it except one of two matters:
The First: That he does not agree with me on what I went to regarding the obligation of the covering garment being loose and ample, not tight such that it delineates the Awrah. And he sees, imitating the Shafi’is, that there is no harm in wearing tight trousers. Consequently, he holds the view I compelled them with: the permissibility of these tight clothes which stick to the body and describe it... etc., because they covered the color. This is what I do not think he holds if there remains with him an atom of intellect and religion! If this is what he means, let him declare it so we may refute him from his Madhhab, if the corruption and temptation resulting from wearing these tight clothes does not convince him of its error...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
...and the correctness of what I went to. For it came in ‘The Chapter of Prohibition and Permissibility’ from the footnote of Ibn Abidin (5/242) after quoting some quotes from the Hanafi scholars regarding tight clothes: ‘And based on this, it is not lawful to look at the Awrah of another over a garment sticking to it describing its size.’

His Thinking That Declaring Error is suspicion of the One in Error, and the Refutation of Him with the Sayings of Scholars
And the other: That he agrees with me on that, but he does not see it correct to openly declare the error of the Shafi’is in their saying of non-obligation, or he sees that declaring error means attacking the opponents. If this is what he means—and this is what is preponderant to me—then this is from his extreme ignorance, or from his cold piety. For declaring error does not necessitate attacking the one in error due to Ijtihad except according to the ignorant. Because the one in error has a single reward as the Messenger, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, declared, and according to the likes of His saying, the Exalted: {There is no blame upon you for that in which you have erred}. So how can it be imagined that two contradictory beliefs combine in the mind of a Muslim at one time: the one in error is rewarded and attacked?! Among the chapters of Al-Hafiz Ibn Abd al-Barr in his book ‘Jami’ Bayan al-Ilm wa Fadlih’: ‘Chapter: Mentioning the evidence in the sayings of the Salaf that difference consists of error and correctness, necessitating seeking proof regarding it, and mentioning some of what they declared each other in error regarding, and what some of them denied of others when they differed.’ Here I am quoting for the noble reader some texts which Al-Hafiz cited in the mentioned chapter, shortening the chains of narration to clarify for him the status of this unjust attacker regarding knowledge of the sayings of the scholars...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
...and their Madhhabs, even if he pretends to be polite with them, but it is a cold politeness which they would not approve from anyone because it is contrary to the etiquette of the Salaf with one another!
1 - From Sa’id bin Jubayr, he said: I said to Ibn Abbas: Indeed Nauf Al-Bikali claims that Moses, the companion of Al-Khidr, is not the Moses of the Children of Israel! He said: He lied!
2 - And Aisha rejected the saying of [Ibn] Umar: The dead is tormented by the weeping of his family over him, and she said: Abu Abd al-Rahman was deluded or erred.
3 - And it was raised to Ali bin Abi Talib that Shuraih judged regarding a man who found a fugitive slave and took him, then he escaped from him: That he guarantees the slave. So Ali said: Shuraih erred and judged poorly. Rather, he swears by Allah that he escaped from him while he did not know, and there is nothing upon him.
4 - And Waki’ narrated from Isma’il bin Abd al-Malik, he said: I asked Sa’id bin Jubayr about a daughter and a cousin, one of whom is a maternal brother? He said: For the daughter is the half, and what remains is for the cousin who is not a maternal brother. He said: And I asked Ata? He said: Sa’id bin Jubayr erred. For the daughter is the half, and what remains is between them in halves.
5 - And Abd al-Razzaq mentioned from Ibn Uyaynah from Isma’il bin Abi Khalid, he said: I said to Al-Sha’bi regarding that Ibrahim said about a man who has a debt owed by a man to a term, so he reduces some for him and hastens some: That there is no harm in it, but Al-Hakam disliked it? So Al-Sha’bi said: Al-Hakam was correct and Ibrahim erred.
6 - And it was said to Sa’id bin Jubayr that Al-Sha’bi says: Umrah is...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
...voluntary. He said: Al-Sha’bi erred.
7 - And the saying of Shuraih regarding the writer (Mukatab) was mentioned to Sa’id bin al-Musayyib, so he said: Shuraih erred.
8 - And Hammam narrated from Qatada that Iyas bin Mu’awiyah permitted the testimony of a man and two women in divorce. Qatada said: So Al-Hasan was asked about that and he said: The testimony of women is not valid in divorce. He said: So I wrote to Umar bin Abd al-Aziz with the saying of Al-Hasan and the judgment of Iyas. So Umar wrote: Al-Hasan was correct and Iyas erred.
Abu Umar Ibn Abd al-Barr said: This is frequent in the books of scholars, and likewise is the difference of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and the Followers and those after them among the successors. What some of them rejected of others can hardly be encompassed by a book, let alone be collected in a chapter. In the returning of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, to one another, and the rejection of some of them against others, is a clear proof that difference according to them is error and correctness. If correctness was in two conflicting aspects, the Salaf would not have declared one another in error in their Ijtihad, their judgments, and their fatwas. Reason refuses that a thing and its opposite be both correct. And he excelled who said:
Affirming two opposites together in a state ... is the ugliest of what comes of impossibilities.
And Ashhab said: I heard Malik saying: The truth is but one. Two different sayings cannot be both correct. The truth and correctness are but one. Ashhab said: And Al-Layth says the same*.
Abu Umar said: Difference is not a proof according to anyone I know of the jurists of the Ummah except one who has no insight and no knowledge with him, and there is no proof in his saying.
foot_note: 1. * It came in the second edition: (to his death with his hoof) instead of (but one. Ashhab said: And Al-Layth says the same), and the established text is from the first edition of the book. [Preparer of the book for Al-Maktaba Al-Shamila]

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
text:
I said: And the basis for the Companions and those after them declaring error of one another, without any discomfort, is the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. For he is the one who established that for them. It is proven in the two Sahihs and others from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq after he interpreted a vision for a man: “You were right in some, and you erred in some.” Such declaration of error did not have any bad effect in their hearts, firstly due to their safety from rancor and suspicion, and secondly due to their knowledge that it does not necessitate any of the attack which is not befitting the right of a Muslim. This is unlike these fanatics whose hearts are filled with hatred and malice against the People of the Sunnah and suspicion of them. The Sunni hardly utters a word of truth as advice, reminder, and teaching, except that the enemies of the Sunnah hasten with their malice and suspicion to interpret it as its opposite. And upon this Abu Ghuddah proceeded in his “Words”, {And those who have wronged are going to know to what [kind of] return they will be returned}.
From what preceded, you know that Abu Ghuddah has returned as a loser and disappointed with this final arrow he directed at me, his state in it being his state in all the arrows and attacks whose exposure and directing back at him has preceded. And such is the state of every sinful aggressor who thinks that by his plotting and scheming he only harms others and blows his poison into them, while the reality is that by that he is like one striving for his death with his own hoof.
I ask Allah the Exalted to discipline us with the etiquettes of Islam, and to character us with the morals of the sincere, truthful believers, whose hearts Allah has purified...

book_title: Unveiling the Falsehoods and Fabrications in Abu Ghuddah's 'Words'
